entry.title: Ruby‚Äôs Each Loop Eventually Ends in Heartbreak

link.title: Ruby‚Äôs Each Loop Eventually Ends in Heartbreak

entry.content:
The Gold Standard

When I began learning Ruby, one of the things I noticed that it was missing a very familiar tool that I had taken for granted in PHP and C++.

That small loop allows for a ton of custom iteration and is found in many programming languages. Ruby‚Äôs replacement of the for loop was taught to me as the each loop, which abstracts out for loop‚Äôs parameters by assuming a programmer will always want to iterate over the elements of an entire set. It adds additional flexibility by using a placeholder for each element to be referenced within the iterative loop.

Many months had passed since that day. Projects were built and frameworks learned, and I slowly forgot about that old loop. Only until today did I realize that Ruby‚Äôs each loop is not a replacement and treating it as such can lead down the wrong path.

Enter Binary Trees

When traversing binary trees one typically uses a data structure known as a queue to make sense of the relationships. The queue is just like a line at Jimmy John‚Äôs: The first person in line is the first person served, and then they exit. Every customer gets processed piece-wise until the lunch rush ends.

In terms of a binary tree, the queue is used in the following manner:

  1. Start with the root of the tree in the queue
  2. Add root‚Äôs children to the queue (if exist)
  3. Remove root from the queue
  4. Begin iterating next queue (now consisting of root‚Äôs children)

Queues are used alongside the Breadth-first search (BFS) algorithm to search through trees. In the midst of building my own BFS algorithm was when I realized that using #each in Ruby for all iterative problems isn‚Äôt appropriate.

Problem & Solution

The problem I was trying to solve was a straightforward one: return the average value of the nodes on each level. I studied this problem for many hours, watched videos on BFS and examined other user‚Äôs solutions. Once I had wrapped my head around how the algorithm worked I then set out to build my own, but reaching for an each loop to solve this led to confusing results that I couldn‚Äôt make out for a long, frustrating time. Note in my solution below how the times loop was used instead of each.

Want to know how many times I have used a times loop to solve an actual programming problem in Ruby? Zero. The Turing School of Software and Design teach the each loop as if it is a perfect stand-in for a for loop, and while that may be true for 99% of programming problems, there would have been no way for me to solve the above problem using an each loop using my approach.

Conclusion

Currently, there are only 5 submissions out of 999+ for a Ruby-based solution to the above problem, which I find hilarious. This experience has opened my eyes into how a language can hinder you if you don‚Äôt examine the assumptions that are made in the inner workings of its de facto iterative loop. The beauty of C‚Äôs for loop is it‚Äôs so low-level there are no assumptions based into it.

Unfortunately, now when I work in Ruby on actual comp-sci topics I have the mental weight of deciding between two different loops instead of having a single de facto one in my toolkit.

entry.title: Tourists in France
entry.content:
There's a misconception that the French are rude...

‚Ä¶ but if I were French I don‚Äôt think I could stand the tourists.

Never have I been in a another country where tourists so readily disregard a country‚Äôs native tongue. During a dinner at a brasserie by the Trocad√©ro in Paris I witnessed the typical American tourist and I could feel nothing but embarrassment.

‚ÄúYou got any bourbon?‚Äù He drawled in lazy English as the waiter looked baffled.

‚ÄúYou know, BURR-BUN WISS-KEY!‚Äù

He made an off-hand comment about the French people as he shooed away the poor waiter with his wine-list. It felt like such a stark contrast in experiences as I enjoyed a superb meal that was made with pride. The steak was beautifully seared and basted; the fries, hand-cut and cooked to perfection. Even the humble side salad was composed of the freshest butter lettuce I‚Äôve ever eaten. The waiter (who was patient with my garbage French) recommended the best pairing of wine that I still dream about to this day‚Äì a red Brouilly ü•∞

Along the northern coast lies a small picturesque town called √âtretat. Kelsie and I picked a small seafood restaurant for dinner and were sat next to another tourist couple. At this point of the trip we had been in France for a little over a week, and I could speak enough French to not rely on English at all in a restaurant‚Äì even if I had to count on my fingers to remember cinq is five üòÖ As I enjoyed my delicious sole meuni√®re, our tourist neighbors took out their phone for the waitress and were insistently pointing to a picture of a lobster. Needless to say, the waitress was incredibly confused‚Äì it wasn‚Äôt on the menu or even remotely native to the area.

I suppose travel only broadens the mind insofar as one allows him/herself to be open to another‚Äôs culture.

entry.title: History of Music Taste (abridged)
entry.content:
When it comes to music, I've been pretty "on the spectrum"...

Before the age of 7 I compulsively listened to my parent‚Äôs Mannheim Steamroller album and the Rusted Root song ‚ÄúSend Me on My Way‚Äù. This obsession with specific songs peaked when I heard Grieg‚Äôs ‚ÄúIn the Hall of the Mountain King‚Äù where I probably listened to it ten times a day for a couple of months. Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross‚Äô rendition for The Social Network soundtrack is also üëåI still enjoy instrumental music a lot these days. Patrick O‚ÄôHearn‚Äôs ‚ÄúBeyond this Moment‚Äù and Erik W√∏llo‚Äôs ‚ÄúSedona‚Äù are just my vibe.

After a pretty intense Weird Al stage, my first ‚Äúreal‚Äù album was Franz Ferdinand‚Äôs self-titled. I‚Äôm notoriously bad at memorizing lyrics, but I listened to this album so much that I know the words not only to their hit ‚ÄúTake Me Out‚Äù, but to the entire album.

For better or worse, my teenage years consisted of entirely indie music‚Äì whatever the hell that means. Modest Mouse was tops though. ‚ÄúLounge (Closing Time)‚Äù and ‚ÄúSpitting Venom‚Äù are two of my faves.

My twenties consisted of a lot of hip-hop, of far more artists than I can name. What an absolutely inventive and varied genre of music. If I had to pick some of my favorites off the top of my head they would be ‚ÄúExhibit A‚Äù by Jay Electronica and Kanye West‚Äôs My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy album.

At some point during this time I had a couple of transformational music experiences:

  1. Hearing this guy‚Äôs acoustic cover of The White Stripe‚Äôs ‚ÄúBall and Biscuit‚Äù which got me into the blues.
  2. Going to a Steel Panther and Judas Priest concert with ‚ÄúTurkey‚Äù and Ashlee which opened my eyes and ears to glorious metal ü§ò As I enter my thirties those two genres are what really resonate with me. They are both very rhythm-centric and many songs are played in the best key (E). So many great riffs were written in E‚Ä¶
entry.summary: When it comes to music, I've been pretty "on the spectrum"...
